etymologies: late 17th century. From French sagamité (G. Sagard 1632) from Montagnais kichagamiteȣ or a similarly-formed Ojibwa (Old Algonquin) word now reflected by Ojibwa gizhaagamide, lit. ‘it is hot liquid’ (from gizhide it is hot + (infixed) -aagam- liquid)

definitions: Among North American Indian peoples: a kind of porridge made from maize. Also: a stew made with this, along with other ingredients such as vegetables, wild rice, beans, and fish.
